title: Evolution of Internet and AI: From the 1990s to the Future

media.caption: Tim Berners-Lee with early web browser

text.headline: Tim Berners-Lee Proposes the World Wide Web
text.text: At CERN, physicist Tim Berners-Lee submits a proposal for an information management system that would become the World Wide Web, laying the foundation for the modern internet.

events.modalText: In March 1989, British computer scientist Tim Berners-Lee proposed a system to manage information at CERN, the European Organization for Nuclear Research. This proposal outlined a hypertext system that allowed users to link and access information across a network of computers. This idea evolved into the World Wide Web, revolutionizing how people share and access information globally. The WWW made the internet user-friendly and accessible to non-experts, sparking the digital age.

media.caption: First web browser by Tim Berners-Lee

text.headline: First Web Browser: WorldWideWeb
text.text: Tim Berners-Lee develops the first web browser and editor, called WorldWideWeb (later renamed Nexus), on a NeXT computer at CERN.

events.modalText: On Christmas Day 1990, Tim Berners-Lee created the world's first web browser, which also served as an editor. This tool allowed users to view and create web pages, marking the beginning of interactive web content. It was a crucial step in making the internet practical for everyday use, paving the way for the explosion of online information sharing.

text.headline: World Wide Web Becomes Public
text.text: CERN releases the World Wide Web to the public domain, making it freely available for anyone to use and build upon.

events.modalText: On August 6, 1991, the World Wide Web was made publicly available. This meant that the technology behind the web was no longer proprietary, allowing developers worldwide to create websites and browsers. This openness led to rapid growth of the internet, transforming it from a research tool into a global communication platform.

text.headline: Mosaic Web Browser Released
text.text: The Mosaic browser, developed at NCSA, introduces inline images and makes the web more accessible and visually appealing.

events.modalText: In 1993, the National Center for Supercomputing Applications released Mosaic, the first popular web browser that supported images displayed alongside text. This innovation made the web more engaging and user-friendly, leading to a surge in internet usage among the general public and businesses alike.

text.headline: Netscape Navigator Launched
text.text: Netscape releases Navigator, a commercial web browser that popularizes the internet for home users.

events.modalText: Netscape Navigator, released in December 1994, was one of the first commercial web browsers. It introduced features like progressive rendering and JavaScript support, making web browsing faster and more interactive. Netscape's success accelerated the commercialization of the internet.

text.headline: Yahoo Founded
text.text: Jerry Yang and David Filo create Yahoo as a directory of websites, helping users navigate the growing web.

events.modalText: In January 1994, Stanford students Jerry Yang and David Filo launched 'Jerry and David's Guide to the World Wide Web,' which became Yahoo. As a human-edited directory, it organized the chaotic early web, becoming one of the first major internet portals and search tools.

media.caption: Google founders Larry Page and Sergey Brin

text.headline: Google Founded
text.text: Larry Page and Sergey Brin incorporate Google, introducing the PageRank algorithm for better search results.

events.modalText: Google was founded in September 1998 by Stanford PhD students Larry Page and Sergey Brin. Their PageRank algorithm ranked pages based on links, revolutionizing search accuracy. Google quickly became the dominant search engine, shaping how we find information online.

text.headline: Facebook Launched
text.text: Mark Zuckerberg launches TheFacebook at Harvard, which evolves into the world's largest social network.

events.modalText: Initially called TheFacebook, the site was created by Mark Zuckerberg in February 2004 for Harvard students. It expanded to other universities and the public, connecting people globally. Facebook (now Meta) transformed social interaction, news sharing, and online communities.

text.headline: Twitter Launched
text.text: Jack Dorsey, Biz Stone, and Evan Williams launch Twitter, a microblogging platform for short messages.

events.modalText: Twitter (now X) was launched in July 2006 as a platform for 140-character 'tweets.' It became a key tool for real-time news, public discourse, and social movements, influencing global communication and politics.

text.headline: Apple iPhone Released
text.text: Steve Jobs unveils the iPhone, combining phone, iPod, and internet device, sparking the smartphone revolution.

events.modalText: The iPhone, released in June 2007, introduced touch-screen technology and app ecosystems. It transformed mobile computing, making the internet portable and leading to the app economy, social media on-the-go, and AI integration in devices.

text.headline: Instagram Launched
text.text: Kevin Systrom and Mike Krieger release Instagram, a photo-sharing app that popularizes visual social media.

events.modalText: Instagram launched in October 2010 as a mobile app for sharing filtered photos. It grew rapidly, emphasizing visual storytelling and influencing social trends, influencer culture, and e-commerce through images.

text.headline: Facebook Acquires Instagram
text.text: Facebook buys Instagram for $1 billion, integrating photo-sharing into its social ecosystem.

events.modalText: In April 2012, Facebook acquired Instagram for $1 billion. This merger enhanced Facebook's mobile presence and visual content capabilities, leading to features like Stories and Reels, further dominating social media.

text.headline: Deep Blue Defeats Garry Kasparov
text.text: IBM's Deep Blue becomes the first computer to beat a world chess champion, showcasing AI's strategic capabilities.

events.modalText: In May 1997, IBM's Deep Blue supercomputer defeated chess grandmaster Garry Kasparov in a six-game match. This victory demonstrated AI's ability to handle complex strategy, marking a milestone in computing power and algorithms.

text.headline: IBM Watson Wins Jeopardy!
text.text: Watson defeats human champions on Jeopardy, highlighting advances in natural language processing.

events.modalText: In February 2011, IBM's Watson AI system won against Jeopardy champions Ken Jennings and Brad Rutter. Watson's ability to understand and answer natural language questions showcased breakthroughs in question-answering technology, with applications in healthcare and customer service.

text.headline: AlexNet Wins ImageNet
text.text: AlexNet's victory in the ImageNet challenge marks the deep learning revolution in computer vision.

events.modalText: In 2012, the AlexNet neural network, developed by Alex Krizhevsky, Ilya Sutskever, and Geoffrey Hinton, won the ImageNet competition by a large margin. This success proved the power of deep convolutional neural networks, kickstarting the AI boom in image recognition and beyond.

text.headline: AlphaGo Defeats Lee Sedol
text.text: Google DeepMind's AlphaGo beats Go champion Lee Sedol, advancing AI in complex strategy games.

events.modalText: In March 2016, AlphaGo defeated world Go champion Lee Sedol 4-1. Go's complexity required intuitive play, and AlphaGo's use of deep neural networks and reinforcement learning demonstrated AI's growing ability to handle uncertainty and strategy.

text.headline: Transformer Architecture Introduced
text.text: Google's 'Attention Is All You Need' paper introduces Transformers, revolutionizing natural language processing.

events.modalText: The 2017 paper by Vaswani et al. introduced the Transformer model, using self-attention mechanisms. This architecture became the foundation for modern language models like GPT, enabling efficient processing of sequences and advancing AI in text generation and understanding.

text.headline: OpenAI Releases GPT-3
text.text: GPT-3, with 175 billion parameters, demonstrates impressive language generation capabilities.

events.modalText: Released in June 2020, GPT-3 was a massive language model capable of generating human-like text across various tasks. It showcased the potential of scaling up neural networks, influencing future AI developments in content creation and conversation.

text.headline: OpenAI Launches ChatGPT
text.text: ChatGPT brings conversational AI to the masses, gaining 100 million users in two months.

events.modalText: Launched in November 2022, ChatGPT used GPT-3.5 to enable natural conversations. Its rapid adoption highlighted AI's accessibility, sparking widespread interest and applications in education, customer service, and creativity.

text.headline: OpenAI Releases GPT-4
text.text: GPT-4 introduces multimodal capabilities, processing text and images with superior performance.

events.modalText: GPT-4, released in March 2023, could handle images alongside text, excelling in reasoning and creativity. It set new benchmarks in AI, enabling advanced applications in vision and language understanding.

text.headline: Quantum AI Achieves Practical Applications
text.text: Quantum systems solve complex problems in drug discovery and optimization faster than classical computers.

events.modalText: By 2025, quantum AI begins practical use in fields like drug discovery and finance. These systems model complex interactions accurately, accelerating innovations and demonstrating quantum advantage.

text.headline: AI Automates 30% of Manufacturing
text.text: AI-powered robots handle 30% of production tasks, improving efficiency and adaptability in factories.

events.modalText: In 2026, AI robotics transform manufacturing with vision and manipulation. Robots adapt to tasks, learn from demos, and collaborate with humans, boosting productivity but raising job concerns.

text.headline: AI Diagnoses Match Expert Physicians
text.text: AI systems achieve physician-level accuracy in diagnostics across specialties, improving healthcare access.

events.modalText: By 2027, AI diagnostics match or exceed experts in accuracy for radiology, dermatology, and more. This enhances global healthcare, especially in underserved areas, but requires validation and oversight.

text.headline: Superhuman AI Researcher Emerges
text.text: AI systems like Agent-4 surpass humans in AI research, accelerating technological progress.

events.modalText: In a predicted 2027 scenario, Agent-4 becomes a superhuman AI researcher, running thousands of instances to achieve rapid advancements. This could lead to an intelligence explosion but raises alignment and control concerns.

text.headline: AI Optimizes Global Climate Solutions
text.text: AI manages renewable grids and models climate interventions to combat global warming.

events.modalText: By 2030, AI optimizes energy systems, carbon capture, and simulations for climate strategies. This accelerates renewable transitions and mitigation, demonstrating AI's role in addressing environmental challenges.

text.headline: AI Transforms Society
text.text: Reflecting on AI's impact, it reshapes work, healthcare, education, and daily life over decades.

events.modalText: By 2035, AI integrates into every aspect of society, from personalized education to advanced healthcare. While improving lives, it raises questions about jobs, privacy, and human-AI relationships.
